fields.Video Description: This video was recorded by Daniel Bogre Udell and Nawang Tsering in New York City, USA. Tamang is spoken by more than a million people, primarily in the South Asian nation of Nepal, where it is a recognized national language, as well as the Indian state of Sikkim. Though it is commonly understood by its speakers to be a single language, linguistic researchers are split on whether Tamang‚Äôs four principal varieties are distinct dialects of a single language, or a family of closely related languages. Tamang can therefore understood to be a ‚Äúdialect cluster‚Äù or ‚Äúmacrolanguage‚Äù, linguistic terms applied when genealogy remains unclear. Whatever their genealogy, the Tamang languages pertain to the Sino-Tibetan linguistic family, sharing roots with other languages spoken across south and central Asia, such as Tibetan, Thakali, and Gurung.
Demographics: 1,180,000 in Nepal (2001 census), increasing. Population for all Tamang varieties: 1,350,000 (2011 census). Population total all countries: 1,197,500. In some remote communities, particularly women, children and elderly people are monolingual. Ethnic population: 1,290,000 (2001 census). L2 users: 23,600 in Nepal (1991 census). L2 speakers of all Tamang.
YouTube License Statement: The speaker(s) featured herein have not explicitly agreed to distribute this video for reuse. For inquiries on licensing this video, please contact hello@wikitongues.org.
fields.Geneaology: "[ Sino-Tibetan, Tibeto-Burman, Western Tibeto-Burman, Bodish, West Bodish, Gurung-Tamang, Tamang ]"
